PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1944, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your complete questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
1.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ........................................... Alfred Nels Rosengquist

2. Your address ........................................... P.O. Box 78 - Bladworth, Sask.

3. Date ........................................... Jan. 1st, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ........................................... New Bedford - Ill., USA

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ........................................... Nels Nelson Rosengquist

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ........................................... May - 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. ........................................... I was 5 years old when my parents moved to Wauka Minnesota.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). ........................................... I was 22 years old. Came through the flood at Humboldt - about 20 miles from Regina

9. What were your reasons for coming West? ........................................... To get a homestead. The Government let me $10. I could not stay for 3 years - but I could work as I am still living at Bladworth.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). ........................................... Agents
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? 
My folks thought it would be alright.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
I came with a friend.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Railroad to homestead flood.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
The homestead flood, I will never forget, so I finished my journey to Davidson, with a man that drove a wagon loaded to Davidson. But as we were on the south side of the flood we had to cross the water that averaged about 3/4 ft. We got stuck about way across so rode horseback to north side of river in the night but we could. The weather was nice at the time, but the water was cold, so there was a lot of snow yet along the banks. It was 1 o'clock next day when we got across & continued on to Davidson. Arriving there on the 16th of May 1907.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
With the man I have just mentioned above.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
On the N.E. ¼ of Sec. 37 - Township 28 Range 1 - west of 3rd meridian about 15 miles north-west of Davidson.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Carpentering.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   2-3 times a year

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage. I got married on the 24th day of June 1909 at Penneck, Minnesota.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled. None.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
    The summer flood was enough for me, as we waded in almost knee deep water from daylight to 1 PM when we got across. We did not wish get a cold from it. I got lost at night several times, but always found my way somewhere.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    No, away to bury - Carpentering & improving my homestead.
25. When was the first car used in the community? I don't remember. I got my Model T Ford in 1965 - costing $555.00.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Brandon at first - later Bloodworth

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? about once a week, if weather permitted

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? almost from start, taking turns, & going with neighbors.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then. Sometimes after I got married.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? in the early 20's - I don't remember but just before I got from Butte to Rural Tel Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? I came to stay, & I am still here.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving? No one moved out as near as I can remember in my district.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return? Just a few, that were not established. New ones came from time to time.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. I was Trustee of Briggs School for 27 years starting when it was organized. I was Board of Directors from local improvement days, till a few years ago. I was also trouble man on all 5 Company lines for a number of years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Briggs School district took its name from the man that the school was built on one corner of his land.
